1592765143_18LjTpx4UtPSFfAZi8kfoyWasJq9g.body: You would need to make a system where people register privately.   Zeronet is technically not a blockchain so ledgers would be impossible without worrying about someone messing with such.    If you create a Tor hidden server and host a web server you could perhaps create a registration then send via email their credentials for their Zeronet account..   You would need people to run something like a Python App that does all the encryption and processing of data...   But the ledger (Blockchain) is actually the really hard part.

> [frankwalter](#comment_32_18LjTpx4UtPSFfAZi8kfoyWasJq9gZCCkV): This thread is not meant for discussions of this type. [...]

There is NO way you an create a P2P crypto exchange on Zeronet...  You would need people to download a python app that you create for data processing and submission.   Creating something private on Zeronet is not possible as everything is in the open for all to see...    You can post encrypted data that you and the individual using your service could see and use Zeronet as a ledger of sorts, kind of like an XML feed...   The python app could update its data from the feed and submit changes to you via Zeronet.

"I'm working on a design to make a truly p2p trading crypto exchange, safe, here on zeronet. Comments?"
Simply not possible purely using Zeronet!  ...  But a python app that works with Zeronet could be a method to do what you want...   Zeronet uses IPFS but the data is still on a server somewhere...    IPFS and Tor handles the DNS aspects via their networks...   You can try to setup a Zeronet site and have a IPFS address point to such BUT that is somewhat more complicated then simply having users run a python app that does all the processing.

1593971855_12MBVCw8iNrKvgTrV5NMPtPf6Z5V2.body: No switching to FreeBSD for most people is not the best idea...   If you are a system administrator who has a background in BSD and prefer it to Linux then either FreeBSD or OpenBSD will be useful to you...   If you use Linux nearly any flavor / distro will be secure...    BSD and Linux were developed during about the same timeline, Linux for most being the more simple of the two.

> [ryuyu5](#comment_3_1F4duoki9FzLS8ck49rNWYv5tYtCru96XS): In 2020 the reason for using FreeBSD at hosting companies might be just adherence to legacy systems and reuse of various administration scripts that have been created over some long time period. In the past the reason was that the FreeBSD operating system processes did not freeze while one of them was waiting for data to arrive from disk. Even the year 2020 Linux distributions still have that problem with the default process scheduler. Easy to test: start copying some huge ISO images from one non-SSD disk to another and the Linux system freezes till the copying operation is complete. Supposedly the modern Linux has an alternative process scheduler available that does not freeze the system in that occasion, but supposedly (I have not tested it) it is in average less efficient than the one that does freeze. [...]

Information helps to clarify why admins kept using BSD for such a long time.

1594580652_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKz.body: You need to HOST and pin the data...  So create an IPFS server, not client, "upload" / connect your file to IPFS then pin it to IPFS.  There needs to be enough nodes for the data to propagate through the public network.   Pinning your data helps keep your data available longer and indicates importance...  The Garbage collector will eventually remove / delete NON pinned content...    You can always unpin your file(s) at a later time...   Fairly Easy!
